characters: PETALUMA HIGH SCHOOL TALENT SHOW / WEDNESDAY APRIL 29, 19
AFTER TEN YEARS OF NORMAL LIFE, I DISCOVER I AM AN ESCAPE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is twilight. Ed lifts the latch on the front gate and, cigarette in his mouth, heads up the walk. Music filters out from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed walks though the living room, hands in his pockets. Th music emanates from a radio in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A track forward reveals Doris sitting at a vanity, doing hair. Her dress is half zipped at the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Gimme a zip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed walks over behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Us! The party at Nirdlinger's--I  told you last week, for the Christmas  Push.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are close on the zipper as Ed's hand takes the tab, pa the lowers it slightly. Her back blooms through the dark  fabric of the dress. He slides the zipper up, and Doris reaches for a perfume  atomizer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, get ready. It's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, go ahead. I'm not big on parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be a grump.

dialogues.speaker: SALES FLOOR
dialogues.text: It is festooned with streamers. Ed leans against a wall, one hand dug into a pocket, the  other bringing a cigarette to his lips. Band music plays and Nirdlinger's employees whirl on the  dance floor. Bobby-soxed teenagers Lindy-hop and pass pal over their knees. A thin young man in a sports coat stands next to Ed, watc his Adam's apple bobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out onto the dance floor. Ed, left by himself, ga across the floor. His view, broken by dancers' crosses, shows Big Dave worr talking to Doris. Doris reacts angrily. Big Dave morosely absorbs the angry words from Doris. He  glances up toward Ed and notices his gaze with consternat He gives Doris a jerk of the head, and she too looks over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in ladies' wear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man with the Adam's apple is back, looking out the floor, snapping his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't I seen you up in ladies'  wear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't work here. My wife does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Some beat, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check out the rack on that broad in  the angora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand is laid on Ed's shoulder. It is Big Dave; he leans to murmur:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed. Can I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: BIG DAVE'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Music from the party drifts in only faintly. The office i built into a corner of the sales floor. It is dominated b large desk. A large window on the far side affords a part view of the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siddown. Siddown...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed sits in a leather chair in front of the desk. Dave fum nervously on top of the desk for a cigar. He trims the en of the cigar with a short double-bladed knife with a stee grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Souveniered it off a Jap in New  Guinea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands one cigar to Ed, takes one for himself, then dra up a chair to face Ed's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I guess you're wondering what  Doris was so hot about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is dark, the only illumination coming from the window onto the bright sales floor behind Big Dave. Ed le forward for Dave to light his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...These're Havanas. Romeo and  Juliets. Private stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, having lit Ed's cigar, draws nervously on his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Dave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave breaks down, weeping. He buries his face in his hand the burning cigar in his right hand perilously close to h hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, I've been weak...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His shoulders heave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've, uh... I've, uh... thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed has taken Dave's cigar so that he won't burn himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've, uh... Oh, Jesus. I've been  carrying on with a married woman.  Uh, no one you know. And now the, uh-- what is it they say?--the--the--the  chickens are coming home to roost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed awkwardly holds the two burning cigars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I, I'm not proud of it. But,  uh, that's not the worst of it. I  got a note. A blackmail note. You  know, come across or everybody knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know what that would do to  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it would be pretty awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward?! Ann'd throw me out on my  keister! Hell, it's her family's  store--*her* store. I serve at the  indulgence of the goddamn ownership,  Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only work here! And the lady's  husband would know... Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much to they want, Dave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: $10,000! I don't know what to do,  Ed. I don't know what I *can* do.  Even though I know who the sonofabitch  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know... who *who* is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sonofabitch. The blackmailer.  It's, uh, it's no one you know. It's  a businessman from Sacramento. A  goddamn pansy, Ed. He tried to rope  me into some crackpot scheme; I heard  him out and then told him to go to  hell. And the very next day, the  very next day, Ed, I get blackmailed  for the same amount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would he... it sounds pretty obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess he don't care that  it's obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm. How, uh... how did he know that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's staying at the hotel I've gone  to with, uh, with the lady in  question. Must've seen us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Dave blows his nose, reaches to take his cigar from E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Thanks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exhales with a long sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why don't you just pay him, Dave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my capitalization on the Annex!  *My* operation, Ed! Christ almighty.  That's what I was just talking to  Doris about, a way of getting the  money from the store that we could  hide from Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embezzling, Ed. From my own goddamn  wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He give a tearful chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Doris, she was pretty hot about  that. God bless her. She doesn't  know I'm telling you this--she's mad  enough already. But Jesus, Ed, you're  the only one I can talk to. I'm, I'm  sorry I... I better get back to the  party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises and clears his throat as he rubs the tears from face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I look all right?

dialogues.speaker: PULLING ED
dialogues.text: He has left the office to wander through an adjacent room lit only by spill from the party. It is the music departm pianos and spinets are arranged across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a way I felt bad for Big Dave. I  knew the ten grand was going to pinch  him where it hurt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed sits on a piano stool next to a standing ashtray. He t out a cigarette, lights it off his cigar, stubs out the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But Doris was two-timing me and I  guess, somewhere, that pinched a  little too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His attention is caught by a distant knock of wood. Someo is raising the key-guard on a piano across the room. The person can only be seen only obscurely, from three- quarters behind, through the sales floor's jumble of  haphazardly arranged instruments. The person begins to pl Ed listens. The piece is slow, sweet, almost a lullaby. The player, unaware that there is an audience, plays on, Ed listens, eyes narrowed against the smoke curling past face. The piece ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The player turns, surprised. It is a young woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Did you make that up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. That was written by Mr Ludwig  van Beethoven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed nods recognition of the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was quite something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wrote some beautiful piano sonatas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was something. I'm Ed Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who you are, Mr Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His look shows surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My father used to take me with  him when he got his hair cut. Walter  Abundas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed's head tilts back in acknowledgment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm Rachel Abundas. Everyone calls  me Birdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I just didn't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's all right. You can't be  expected to remember every skinny  girl who comes in with her dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed give a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You don't like the music out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK, I guess. No, I don't really.  I'm not big on music, ordinarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman calls sharply from offscreen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks. Silhouetted in the doorway to the party room is Doris, co over her arm, purse in hand.

dialogues.speaker: ED'S CAR
dialogues.text: Doris and Ed are driving home. Doris draws heavily on a cigarette, looking flintily out the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What a knucklehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Money problems. He's thinking  about canceling the Annex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *That means I don't run Nirdlinger's!*

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride in silence for a beat. Doris shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What a knucklehead.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: As the car roars past and into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER STREET
dialogues.text: It is day. We are looking from inside a parked car toward hotel entrance. Big Dave emerges from the hotel, gets int Packard and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Dave did it, though...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, sitting in his car, is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I sent a note telling him where  to drop the money...

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ed emerges from a stairwell and goes to a standing ashtra by the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and he did. He came across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed reaches into the trash hole in the ashtray column and  pulls out a Nirdlinger's bag. He goes back to the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER FLOOR
dialogues.text: Ed emerges from the stairwell, goes to a door and knocks. The door swings open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, good, how are ya, come in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed follows him into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You bring a check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cash?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Ed a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Usually we do this kind of thing  with a bank draft. But cash--that's  fine--it's all the same in the end-- dough's dough, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the paperwork here. Partnership  papers here, they reflect our  agreement: fifty-fifty on the net, I  supply professional services, you  supply the capital. I'll give you a  receipt on the dough there, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty straightforward, but I don't  know if you wanna show this stuff to  a lawyer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, screw 'em, huh? Pay 'em to  tangle it up and then you pay 'em to  untangle it, what's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He perspires as he counts the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Just a second here, I'll give you  a receipt on the, uh... Whoa,  Nellie... Oh, by the way, we didn't  talk about this, I, uh, I think I'm  gonna call the place Tolliver's,  after me, you know, I didn't think  you were much interested in, uh--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, good. Lemme just, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wipes his brow, finishes counting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, that's it. As per our  discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creighton hands Ed an executed agreement and a receipt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there it is. Writ large in  legal escriture, next step is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, uh... Creighton...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Creighton a level stare, smoke pluming from the  cigarette planted in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You're not gonna screw me on this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Screw* you--Jesus! Take it to a  lawyer! No, I insist! This is *dry*  cleaning, this is not some fly-by- night thing here! I must say, I've  been an entrepreneur for thirteen  years and I've never--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've never been asked--Look, you  want the dough back? You know who I  am! You--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creighton mops his brow again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, uh... Tolliver's is OK then?

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: Ed drives with the usual cigarette in his mouth. Doris si next to him. Rural scenery slips by in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day was Saturday. We were  going to a reception for Doris' cousin  Gina, who'd just married a wop vintner  out near Modesto. Doris didn't much  feel like going, and I didn't either,  but, like she said, we had a  Commitment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris gazes stonily out at the road. At length:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I hate wops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed gives her a brief glance. Doris glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What's so damn strange about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back out at the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...*You* didn't have to grow up with  'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This brings nothing from Ed. Doris shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Family. Boy.

dialogues.speaker: BY A BARN
dialogues.text: Wops in Sunday clothing greet each other around tables pi with food. A small child runs up to his mother, yanks on her dress a screams:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's ridin' Garibaldi! Uncle Frankie's  ridin' Garibaldi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by cheering children, with a jug of wine slung over his shoulder, Frank is riding an enormous pig. He sl at the pig's ass with a large straw hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was when she started drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris is standing by one of the tables, drinking red wine from a water glass. Ed stands nearby. A large woman hugs Doris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin', Doris, you been OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you, Constanza?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, I got my healt'. And  how you been, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed. How's a business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Doris) He's a barber, right? It's a good  trade. So how come you got no kids?

dialogues.speaker: PICNIC TABLE
dialogues.text: A group of kids pulls Frank, laughing, by the hand toward picnic table set out with pies in a row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Frankie's gotta join! Wait for  Frankie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, come on, kids--I just ate lunch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no--Uncle Frankie's gotta join!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old man stands by with a stopwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks the timer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and the line of children plunge their faces into th line of blueberry pies. The other picnickers cheer them on.

dialogues.speaker: ELSEWHERE
dialogues.text: Ed and Doris approach the innocent-looking young couple  accepting congratulations. Doris, holding her empty glass, is not a happy drunk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Gratulations, Gina. It's so goddamn  wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Gina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is so goddamn wonderful, you  almost won't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a goddamn bowl of cherries,  I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed tries to lead her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris calls back over her shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations on your goddamn  cherries!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ed and Doris recede we hear her petulant:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Leggo my goddamn elbow.

dialogues.speaker: ELSEWHERE
dialogues.text: In a long shot we see Frank at the crest of a hill, stagg slowly, painfully, toward a tree. In his right hand he  clutches a trophy. When he reaches the tree he swings his free hand up again it, leans forward, and vomits.

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: Late afternoon, driving home. Ed drives. Doris sits in the front passenger seat, snorin lightly. Frank sits in the back seat hugging his trophy t his chest, eyes closed, murmuring:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never wanna see another blueberry  pie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I never even wanna hear those  words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris moans. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Don't says those words, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is twilight. Ed's coupe is parked in the driveway. He just rounding the back of the car to open the passenger-s door. He pulls Doris from the car, half asleep, half drun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings open and Ed stumbles in supporting Doris, who has one arm draped around his neck. He helps her into the bedroom and eases her onto the bed. He sits on the edge of the bed and looks down at her. Shadows from branches just outside wave across her face. is breathing through her open mouth; her face is moist wi perspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd met Doris blind on a double-date  with a loudmouthed buddy of mine who  was seeing a friend of hers from  work. We went to a movie; Doris had  a flask; we killed it. She could put  it away. At the end of the night she  said she liked it I didn't talk much.  A couple weeks later she suggested--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A harsh jangle from the telephone. Doris moans but does n wake; Ed rises and does to the living room and picks up t phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, it's Big Dave. I gotta talk to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What--now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm at Nirdlinger's. Let yourself  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. He nudges Doris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rolls away and burrows into a pillow. Ed opens her purse and pokes through it.

dialogues.speaker: NIRDLINGER'S
dialogues.text: We are looking over Ed's shoulder as he hesitantly swings open a door. It reveals Big Dave's office, quiet and rather dark. A down-facing banker's lamp on the desk illuminates Big D hands on the desktop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Dave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed enters, sits. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What's the problem, Big Dave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm ruined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hands writhe on the desktop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It ruined me. This money. No annex.  I'm all shot to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you paid the guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Dave stares without speaking. After a long beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What kind of man *are* you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of man *are* you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Dave--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd understand if you'd walked in  here. Socked me in the nose. Whatever.  I deserved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not proud of what I did. But  *you*.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one talks. Big Dave sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, I paid up. As you well know.  And then I went and found the pansy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Got nothin' to say, huh? Yeah,  well, you already know the story. I  didn't, I hadda beat it out of the  pansy. *Your* money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What kind of man *are* you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Dave rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses around the desk and adds, sadly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm all shot to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed starts to rise, but Big Dave is already looming over h Big Dave bear-hugs him and then spins him into a wall. Ed hits the wall and bounces off, back into Big Dave. Big Dave wallops him in the stomach. Ed doubles over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What kind of man *are* you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Dave hurls him against the desk, then slams his face  against the desktop. Ed's hands scrabble at the top of th desk as Big Dave grabs him by the neck and lifts. He slam him face-first into the window between the office and the dark sales floor. Ed twists around, the back of his head now pressed agains the glass. Big Dave's hands lock around his throat. Big Dave sweats and strains. A crack shoots up the pane of glass. Ed's hand sweeps up and plunges something into Big Dave's neck. Big Dave grunts and turns away, gurgling. His hands go up his throat. Ed watches. He is holding Big Dave's cigar trimmer. Big Dave takes a couple of deliberate steps backward, his head twisted away. He falls back, tripped up by a chair, which spins him fac down onto the floor. Big Dave crawls away face-down across the floor, on his k but with his hands still at his throat. His face and knee awkwardly support his weight as if he were pushing someth across the floor with his nose. He reaches a corner but still pushes forward, wedging him in, legs still scraping away as if to push himself throug the wall. Blood is pooling out from under him. Big Dave's legs are still working. His gurgling continues Ed watches. Big Dave's legs start to move furiously. They convulse. H whole body shakes as he goes into shock. Ed watches. Big Dave stops shaking. He remains wedged awkwardly into corner, face-down. He is still. The room is very quiet. Ed looks down at his hands. He walks across the room, pushes the door open and walks  across the darkened sales floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed walks to his car. He does not look about, is not  particularly furtive. He gets into the car. He starts the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls up, sits motionless for a beat. Gradually, somet draws his attention; he cocks his head and looks up throu the windshield. A branch creaks and sways in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed gets into bed next to Doris. He stares at the ceiling. Wind rustles outside. The shadow of a branch on the ceiling nods in time with t wind. He looks at Doris. Her face is still lightly sheened with sweat but her mout is closed now, her breathing more peaceful. The leafy sha play over her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It was only a couple of weeks  after we met that Doris suggested  getting married. I said, Don't you  wanna get to know me more? She said,  Why, does it get better? She looked  at me like I was a dope, which I've  never really minded from her. And  she had a point, I guess. We knew  each other as well then as now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is gazing at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Anyway, well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound and image face.

dialogues.speaker: BARBERSHOP
dialogues.text: The next day. Ed cuts hair, a cigarette between his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy-moly, do I got a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is giving a haircut as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How you today, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't got a headache?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, I got a headache to beat the  band.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Ed sits in his chair, hands folded in his lap, head tilte back, eyes closed. We hold on Ed as we hear a clipper buzzing and Frank talk to someone in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya can't pump it. Did ya pump it?  That'll just flood it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya gotta pump it. Ya can't just hold  it down. *That'll* flood it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You crazy? You pumped it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ya can't hold it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the jingle of the door bell. Ed opens his eyes. Two men in fedoras are entering. Ed starts to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Crane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: The two men are staring at the sidewalk, smoking, hesitan to speak. One of them finally comes up with an icebreaker

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So you're a barber, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Officer Persky. This is Krebs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed nods toward their car:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed holds up one hand with its smoking cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Uh... Pete's got some news  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His partner gives Persky a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Look, pal, it's a tough break,  but, uh... well damnit, your wife's  been pinched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sent us to tell ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sent us to tell ya. We pulled  the detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My *wife*?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, uh, they brung her to the county  jail, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, embezzlement. And homicide. A  guy named David Brewster. He's, uh...  He's the decedent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the dead guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, it's a tough break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visiting ends at five. Too late today.  You can see her tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, pal. They sent us to tell ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Crap detail.

dialogues.speaker: RESIDENTIAL STREET
dialogues.text: It is evening. Ed is pulling up to a house on a tree-line street similar to his own. He gets out of his car and goe up the walk, and a man sitting on the porch swing holds u hand of greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Lo, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps up on the porch. The man is holding a tumbler of whiskey and ice that clin as the swing moves. His skin glistens with drinker's swea and he has the slightly expansive manner of someone who's put at least a couple away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed glances around but the swing is the only seat. He sits next to Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Thanks for seeing me, at  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hell. Drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you don't need one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Boy. Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What do I, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course, I, uh, it's out of  my league, criminal stuff. I do, uh,  probate, real estate, title search,  uh... I'd be absolutely worthless,  something like this. Absolutely  worthless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He belches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, just finished dinner. Um.  Frankly, Doris'd be better off with  the county defender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He a good man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert's OK, sure, he's a good man. I  won't kid you though, Ed, nobody  around here has any experience with  this kind of, er... And I hear they're  bringing a prosecutor up from  Sacramento. Capital offense. Taking  it seriously... Hmm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking it seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, who should I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens and someone speaks through the scree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want any coffee, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed looks around at the voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Mr Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps out: it is Birdy Abundas. Ed rises, and they awkwardly shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry... I was sorry to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Nice to see you, Mr Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch her go back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit! She's a good kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed nods. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So, uh, who should I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's Lloyd Garroway in San  Francisco. Probity--you know, no one  ever said anything iffy about Lloyd  Garroway. Conservative. Jury might  like that. Might like that here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a sip of his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Probity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Is he the best then, for,  uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the best, the money-is-no-object  best, for a criminal case, any lawyer  would tell you Freddy Riedenschneider.  Out of Sacramento. 'Course, I don't  know how you're fixed for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. He's the, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, Riedenschneider. Wish I  could tell you more. Hell, I wish I  could handle it myself. But I'd be  absolutely worthless for this kind  of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a musing sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Criminal matter? Freddy  Riedenschneider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No question about it.

dialogues.speaker: ED AT A TABLE
dialogues.text: It is a long table with chairs stretching down both sides one side for prisoners, the other for visitors. The room empty except for a guard and an elderly woman who sits ac from a younger woman at the far end of the table. The you woman, in a prison smock, is wailing. The elderly woman i holding her hand. Ed sits across from an empty chair, clutching a flower-pr toiletries kit. There are echoing voices suggesting large spaces outside the room. He sits and waits. Approaching footsteps. The door opens. A large prison matron steps aside to let  Doris enter. Doris looks lost in a prison-issue jumper that is too big for her. Her hair is uncurled and bedraggled. Not only is she not made-up, she has a couple of bruises and a cut on her lip. As Ed stands, she gives a hollow look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey... I brought your make-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's going on. I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't know what happened to Big  Dave. I know some of it.  Irregularities in my books, they  said. Can I explain it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I helped him cook the books, Ed. I  did do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to tell them anything.  We're getting you a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris doesn't seem to be listening. She sighs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know all about that. But I don't  know how much to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell 'em anything. We're getting  you Freddy Riedenschneider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris finally looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I... should I tell you why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to tell me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her gaze drifts away again. She notices the sobbing woman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris looks around and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...My books used to be perfect. Anyone  could open them up, make sense of  the whole goddamn store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew we'd pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: BARBERSHOP
dialogues.text: Ed sits in a waiting-customer chair, wearing his smock. F paces in front of him. He smacks a fist into his palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what family is for, Ed! This  is when ya come together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close ranks! Goddamnit! Those sons  of bitches!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, uh, you know I'll try to  contribute, but, uh--Freddy  Riedenschneider--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what it costs! This is  when ya come together!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very generous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell with it, Eddie!

dialogues.speaker: BANK
dialogues.text: Ed and Frank sit waiting on a bench in the high-vaulted l Frank looks uncomfortable in an ill-fitting suit. As they wait, he looks nervously about. In a hushed voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just people like you and me,  Ed. Remember that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just people. They gotta put up the  big front so that people will trust  them with their money. This is why  the big lobby, Ed. But they put their  pants on one leg at a time. Just  like you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They too use the toilet, Ed. In spite  of appearances. And their money will  be secured by the barbershop. A rock.  A *rock*, the barbershop. I mean,  how long has *this* place been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens. A conservatively dressed man of late middle age emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Raffo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank hops to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you come with me please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Can Ed come too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man looks dubiously at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crane. Ed Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You also have an interest in the  securing property?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a barber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's family, he's my brother-in- law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-hah. It would be best if he waited  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the glass-paned doorway to his office, Frank  trailing dejectedly behind. They enter, the door closes, we hear their muffled voices from inside, the sense of th words lost. Ed sits and watches the two men perform their pantomime o business: Frank nervously reads documents with one hand c to his forehead for concentration; the banker passes  successive documents across his desk with a word of  explanation for each as Frank signs. Ed takes out a cigarette and lights it, watching impassiv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barbershop. Doris and Frank's  father had worked thirty years to  own it free and clear. Now it got  signed over to the bank, and the  bank signed some money over to Frank,  and Frank signed the money over...

dialogues.speaker: POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: It is midday. We are tracking along the sidewalk toward a long cream-colored Packard parked at the curb. A couple o kids have stopped to peer into the car's windows; the car no doubt the fanciest in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to Freddy Riedenschneider, who  got into town two days later...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, coming up the sidewalk, looks up at the storefront: a restaurant with a large window with a plush red drape tha obscures the interior. Gilt lettering on the window spell out "DaVinci's".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and told me to meet him at  DaVinci's for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: Inside the restaurant. We are tracking toward a table who lone occupant sits with his back to us holding open a men as he orders from a facing waitress:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not fried, poached. Three of 'em  for two minutes. A strip steak medium  rare, flapjacks, potatoes, tomato  juice, and plenty of hot coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips the menu over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Do you have prairie oysters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then bring me a fruit cocktail while  I wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You're Ed Crane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barber, right? I'm Freddy  Riedenschneider. Hungry? They tell  me the chow's OK here. I made some  inquiries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress sets a fruit cocktail in front of  Riedenschneider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't wanna waste your time  so I'll eat while we talk. Ya mind?   *You* don't mind. So while I'm in  town I'll be staying at the Hotel  Metropole, the Turandot Suite. Yeah,  it's goofy, the suites're named after  operas; room's OK though, I poked  around. I'm having 'em hold it for  me on account of I'll be back and  forth. In addition to my retainer,  you're paying hotel, living expenses,  secretarial, private eye if we need  to make inquiries, headshrinker should  we go that way. We'll talk about  appeals if, as and when. For right  now, has she confessed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Of course not. She didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! That helps. Not that she didn't  do it, that she didn't confess. Of  course, there's ways to deal with a  confession, but that's good!--one  less thing to think about. Now.  Interview. I'm seeing her tomorrow.  You should be there. Three o'clock.  One more thing: you keep your mouth  shut. I get the lay of the land, I  tell *you* what to say. No talking  out of school. What's out of school?  Everything's out of school. I do the  talking; you keep your trap shut.  I'm an attorney, you're a barber;  you don't know anything. Understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! Any questions give me a ring-- Turandot suite; if I'm out leave a  message. You sure you don't want  anything? No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points a finger at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You're OK, pal. You're OK, she's  OK. Everything's gonna be hunky-dory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress puts down a plate of steak and eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And the flapjacks, honey.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVING POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: We are looking at pedestrians on the sidewalk through the windshield of a moving car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All going about their business. It  seemed like I knew a secret--a bigger  one even then what had really happened  to Big Dave, something none of them  knew...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Ed, driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Like I had made it to the outside,  somehow, and they were all still  struggling, way down below.

dialogues.speaker: ED IN BED
dialogues.text: Arms folded behind his head, staring at the ceiling. On the ceiling is the moving shadow of a tree limb. A distant, muffled knock. Ed turns his head.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Ed opens it as he finishes cinching a bathrobe. The woman waiting on the front porch is dressed in black: black dress and a black veiled hat that is too big for he bird-like frame. Wind rustles in the trees behind her. She stares at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, we hear her speak, in a low, tremulou voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann. Will you come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No, No, it's very late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed nods. After an uncomfortable beat, through which she continues stare:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm so sorry about your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, you know, Doris had nothing  to do with it. Nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lays a black-gloved hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know. Don't worry, Ed. I came  to tell you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ann?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you should tell Doris...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She falls silent. The trees behind her rustle. She gives a wary look back. Then, confidingly, to Ed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You know how Big Dave loved  camping. And the out-of-doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is puzzled:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went camping last summer. In  Eugene, Oregon. *Outside* of Eugene,  Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a searching look, hoping, it seems, that he will find this significant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At night, there were lights--we both  saw them. We never told anyone,  outside of our official report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spacecraft. I saw the creatures.  They led Big Dave onto the craft. He  never told anyone what they did,  outside of his report. Of course he  told *me*. No one else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The government knows. I cannot repeat  it to you. But this thing goes deep,  Ed. This was not your wife. I goes  deep, and involves the government.  There is a great deal of fear. You  know how certain circles would find  it--the knowledge--a threat. They  try to limit it, and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ann, will you come in, sit down,  maybe have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes knowledge is a curse, Ed.  After this happened, things changed.  Big Dave... he never touched me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed says nothing. She touches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Tell Doris not to worry. I know  it wasn't her. Perhaps this will  bring it out, finally. Perhaps now  it will all come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and heads down the walk. Her high-heeled footsteps echo on the walk, then the side then are lost in the rustle of leaves. Ed watches her go: a small black figure, growing smaller.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON MEETING ROOM
dialogues.text: It is an unadorned room with a simple wooden table and ch One high window lets in a shaft of sunlight. Ed and Doris sit at the table; Freddy Riedenschneider sta to one side staring up at the high window, hands dug into his pockets. All three are motionless for a long beat. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It stinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care it's true, it's not  true; it stinks. You say he was being  blackmailed; by who? You don't know.  For having an affair; with who? You  don't know. Did anyone else know  about it? Probably not; you don't  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew about it. Big Dave told me  about it, and the spot he was putting  himself in by getting the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific. Your husband backs you up.  That's terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You've gotta give me something to  work with. Freddy Riedenschneider is  good, but he's not a magician. He  can't just wave his little wand in  the air and make a plausible defense  materialize. Look. Look at what the  other side is gonna run at us. They  got the company books, prepared by  you--*cooked* by you--that's Motive.  They got a murder scene *you* had  access to. That's Opportunity. They  got that little trimmer thing he was  stabbed in the throat with--a *dame's*  weapon--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Big Dave's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --don't interrupt me--that's Means.  They got a fine upstanding pillar of  the business community as a victim,  and then they got *you*, a disgruntled  number-juggling underling who on the  day in question was drunk as a skunk  and whose alibi for the time in  question is being passed out at home,  alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *I* was with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider gives him a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Like I say, it stinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider eyes him. Wheels start turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, we forget the blackmail. *You*  killed him. How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Doris... were having an affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris eyes him. His manner does not reveal anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, how did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... just knew. A husband knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will anyone else say they knew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get into the store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took Doris's keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will anyone say they saw you there?  On your way there? In there? On your  was back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will anyone corroborate and goddamn  part of your story at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed returns Riedenschneider's stare. Riedenschneider resum pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Come on, people. You can't help  each other like that. Let's be  realistic now. Let's look at our  options. Well, frankly, I don't *see*  any options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nod of the head indicates Doris:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I cannot present Story A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another nod indicates Ed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I cannot present Story B. I could  plead you for a nutcase but you look  too composed. I could offer a guilty  plea and in return they don't give  you the juice, but I don't think you  want to spend the rest of your life  in Chino and I know you didn't hire  Freddy Riedenschneider to hold your  hand at a sentencing hearing. Hell,  you could've gotten Lloyd Garroway  for that. No, we're not giving up  yet; you hired Freddy Riedenschneider,  it means you're *not* throwing in  the towel. I litigate, I don't  capitulate. All right, no options,  we gotta think. All right, we go  back to the blackmail thing. It  titillates, it's open ended...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His pacing becomes more animated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And it makes *him* the bad guy-- ya dig around, ya never know,  something unsavory from his past, he  approaches you to help with the money,  it's too late, his past comes back  to haunt him, who's to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is heading for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah. OK. Forget the jealous  husband thing, that's silly; we're  going with the blackmail. I'll be in  touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL LOBBY
dialogues.text: The camera drifts in toward the reception desk. Ed talks the clerk behind the desk, but the scene plays silently; hear only Ed's narration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, there was *one* person  who could confirm Doris's story, or  plenty of it: the dry-cleaning  pansy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The desk clerk is shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But he'd left the hotel, skipped  out on his bill...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: It is a rooming-house hallway. A stern middle-aged woman on the hall telephone. This too plays silently under the  narration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd also disappeared from the  residence he gave me...

dialogues.speaker: ED'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: We are drifting in toward Ed, who nods at the telephone a then cradles it. He stares down at the business card he h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...owing two month's rent. How could  I have been so stupid. Handing over  $10,000. For a piece of paper. And  the man gone... like a ghost...

dialogues.speaker: PULLING BACK FROM ED
dialogues.text: In a different living room. He sits on a sofa, hands clas behind his head, listening. For the first time, as the vo over continues, we hear atmosphere from the scene: piano  music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...disappeared into thin air,  vaporized, like the Nips at Nagasaki.  Gone now. All gone. The money gone.  Big Dave gone. Doris going. How could  I have been so stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The continuing pull-back reveals Walter Abundas on a near chair, also listening as Birdy plays. Walter holds a drink in one hand; he is nodding; his eyel droop. As the piano piece reaches its mournful conclusion his chin alights on his chest, his eyelids tremble closed and he starts lightly to snore.

dialogues.speaker: BARBERSHOP
dialogues.text: The distinctive buzz of electric hairclippers bangs in at the cut. Ed and Frank stand behind their respective chair administering haircuts. The customer in Ed's chair is in white shirtsleeves that not hide rolls of fat. He has a hot towel over his face t does not slow his speech, although it does muffle it to s extent:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes this stuff, she calls it  gatto, it's got egg in there, it's  got sugar, it's got--it's cake,  basically, except she calls it gatto.  Like if you don't call it cake maybe  you won't put on any weight, like I  need to eat gatto, you know what I'm  saying? This stuff, if I've had a  square meal, I've had my steak and  potatoes, I can just have another  cup of coffee afterward, I won't ask  for the desert if it's not there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice turns into a drone under the narration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sooner or later everyone needs a  haircut...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got the recipe from a magazine,  woman's magazine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were working for the bank now. We  kept cutting the hair, trying to  stay afloat, make the payments, tread  water, day by day, day by day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside a courtroom we boom down toward the defendant's ta the fat customer's drone turning into the drone of the ba reading an indictment. Doris stands next to Freddy  Riedenschneider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most people think someone's accused  of a crime, they haul 'em in and  bring 'em to trial, but it's not  like that, it's not that fast. The  wheels of justice turn slow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...did willfully and with malice  aforethought take the life of one  David Allen Brewster, a human being...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have an arraignment, and then  the indictment, and they entertain  motions to dismiss, and postpone,  and change the venue, and alter this  and that and the other. They empanel  a jury, which brings more motions,  and they set a trial date and then  change the date, and then often as  not they'll change it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What say you to these charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our boom down has ended close on Doris. We hear Freddy  Riedenschneider, off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We plead not guilty, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: BARBERSHOP
dialogues.text: Booming down toward the fat man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And through all of it we cut the  hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, Honey, if you're gonna make a  cobbler, make a little bit of cobbler,  don't put a whole pan in front of me  and tell me it's not gonna be any  good when it's cold...

dialogues.speaker: OPERA SINGERS
dialogues.text: We are panning photographic portraits of opera singers in character, wearing the wardrobe of different eras, armies dukedoms, and boudoirs, and displaying the heights and de of various emotions, their mouths stretched wide in song. pan off the pictures to discover that we are in a hotel r floating in toward a bed on which Freddy Riedenschneider, mask over his eyes, slumbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Meanwhile, Freddy Riedenschneider  slept at the Metropole...

dialogues.speaker: RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Tracking in toward Freddy Riedenschneider, who sits twirl spaghetti with a fork against a spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and shoveled it in at DaVinci's.

dialogues.speaker: LATERAL TRACK
dialogues.text: From inside a car. Pedestrians bustle along a sidewalk. A them scurries a weedy little man who has one hand clamped the crown of his hat to keep it in place in a stiff wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd brought in a private investigator  from Sacramento...

dialogues.speaker: LATERAL TRACK
dialogues.text: Moving the opposite way. A different day, but again a cro moves along the sidewalk, and among them the little man  scuttles in the opposite direction, hand still raised to hat, his forearm and the tilt of his head largely obscuri his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to nose around into Big Dave's  past.

dialogues.speaker: PUSHING IN TO ED
dialogues.text: In the Abundas living room again, again listening to Bird at the piano, but now the two of them are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found myself more and more going  over to the Abundas's. It was a  routine we fell into, most every  evening. I even went when Walter was  away on his research trips. He was a  genealogist, had traced back his  side of the family seven generations,  his late wife's, eight. It seemed  like a screwy hobby. But then maybe  all hobbies are. Maybe Walter found  something there, in the old county  courthouses, hospital file rooms,  city archives, property rolls,  registries, something maybe like  what I found listening to Birdy play.  Some kind of escape. Some kind of  peace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The piano music ends in a sustain which begins to fade, b then is snapped by a sharp clang.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON DOOR SWINGS OPEN
dialogues.text: We are pushing into the high-windowed prison meeting room None of its three occupants is moving. The tableau consists of Doris staring down at the table; private investigator sitting on a straightbacked chair ti back against a wall, his arms folded across his chest, hi fedora pushed back on his head, a toothpick clamped betwe his teeth; and Freddy Riedenschneider, standing, hands cl behind his back, gazing with a distant smile up into the  shaft of light that slants through the high window. A warder shuts the door behind Ed. Doris and the private investigator turn to note his entra Riedenschneider does not. Ed pulls out a chair across from Doris, clasps his hands top of hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Lo, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at his hands on top of hers. A long beat. Still gazing up into the shaft of light, Freddy  Riedenschneider announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They got this guy, in Germany.  Fritz something-or-other. Or is it.  Maybe it's Werner. Anyway, he's got  this theory, you wanna test something,  you know, scientifically--how the  planets  go round the sun, what  sunspots are made of, why the water  comes out of the tap--well, you gotta  look at it. But sometimes, you look  at it, your looking *changes* it. Ya  can't know the reality of what  happened, or what *would've* happened  if you hadden a stuck in your goddamn  schnozz. So there *is* no 'what  happened.' Not in any sense that we  can grasp with our puny minds. Because  our minds... out minds get in the  way. Looking at something changes  it. They call it the 'Uncertainty  Principle.' Sure, it sounds screwy,  but even Einstein says the guy's on  to something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His gaze up at the window breaks. He strolls around the r still smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Science. Perception. Reality.  Doubt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops to examine a bur on his fingernail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Reasonable doubt. I'm sayin',  sometimes, the more you look, the  less you really know. It's a fact. A  proved fact. In a way, it's the only  fact there is. This heinie even wrote  it out in numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at the private detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Burns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a slight weight shift, Burns tips his chair so that front legs slap down onto the floor. He fishes a small  notebook from an inside pocket. His boredom is profound; his only concession to performan is to move the toothpick from one side of his mouth to th other where, perhaps, it will less inhibit speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subject: David Allen Brewster. Born:  Cincinnati, 1911. Father: insurance  salesman; mother: homemaker. One  year Case Western University on  football scholarship. Flunks out.  1931: retail appliance salesman in  Barnhoff's department store,  Cincinnati. 1933: meets Ann  Nirdlinger, married later that year,  moves here. 1935: arrested on an  assault complaint; complainant, an  organizer for the ILGWU, has a broken  nose, couple of ribs, wife's family  intercedes, some kind of settlement,  charges dropped. 1936: another assault  beef, bar altercation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, couple of fistfights. Go  to his service record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns looks at him sourly. He flips a couple of pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Inducted March 15, 1942, assigned  to fifth fleet US Navy, petty officer  first class, serves in clerical  capacity in US naval shipyards in  San Diego, one fistfight broken up  by MPs, no court martial, honorable  discharge May 8, 1945. Since then  he's been clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider nods, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Thank you, Burns, get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burns pockets his notebook, adjusts his hat, jams his han into his pockets, and ambles out of the room. The slam of the door leaves quiet. At length:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider's fixed smile now fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? *So?!* This could be your dolly's  ticket out of the deathhouse, so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Doris look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, chum, this is a guy, from what  I understand, told everybody he was  a war hero, right? Island hopping,  practically liberated the Pacific  all by himself with a knife in one  hand and a gun in the other and twenty  yards of Jap guts between his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now it turns out this dope spent  the war sitting on his ass in some  boatyard in San Diego. You asked for  blackmail, let me give you blackmail:  Mr Hale-Fellow-Well-Met, about to  open his own business here, has been  lying to everybody in this town for  the last four years, probably  including half the people sitting on  that jury. Well, it finally caught  up with him--these dopes, it always  does; someone threatened to spill  it. Somebody knew his dirty little  secret, just like your wife says.  They called, they demanded money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is looking at Doris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Did Big Dave mention that it was  something about his war service? I  don't know, I wasn't there, *you'll*  have to tell *us*. Maybe he specified,  maybe he didn't; I'm not putting  words in your mouth; the point is  that this liar, this cynical  manipulator, this man who through  his lies sneered and belittled the  sacrifice and heroism of all our  boys who *did* serve and bleed and  puke and die on foreign shores, and  who made a fool out of this entire  town, turns to *you* to help him out  of his jam. Fat-assed sonofabitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... who... who actually--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? *Who?!* I don't know who! But  the point is that if Mr Prosecutor  over there had devoted half the time  he's spent persecuting *this* woman  to even the most cursory investigation  of this schmoe's past, then we might  *know* who! But we can't *know* what  really happened! Because of Fritz,  or Werner, or whatever the hell his  name is! And because Me Prosecutor  is *also* a lazy fat-assed sonofabitch  who decided it's easier to victimize  your wife! Because it's easier *not*  to look! Because the more you look,  the less you know! But the beauty of  it is, we don't *gotta* know! We  just gotta show that, goddamnit,  *they* don't know. Reasonable doubt.  Science. The atom. *You* explain it  to me. Go ahead. Try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chuckles as he heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, Freddy Riedenschneider sees  daylight. We got a real shot at this,  folks. Let's not get cocky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door shuts behind him. Doris stares down at the table, as at the head of the sce A silent beat; a smile starts to tug at the corners of he mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile twitches, and then stays. Doris starts to laugh Ed frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her laughter builds, almost to hysteria. Finally it subsi and, still staring at the tabletop and smiling, she shake her head:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a dope.

dialogues.speaker: ABUNDAS LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Ed sits listening as Birdy plays. She talks, after a mome her eyes on the sheet music:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was deaf when he wrote this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beethoven. He created it, and yet he  never actually heard it. I suppose  he heard it all in his head, somehow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over her continued playing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So maybe Riedenschneider could get  Doris off. Maybe it would all work  out. And I thought--I hoped--that  maybe there was a way out for me as  well...

dialogues.speaker: A SIGN
dialogues.text: The cardboard sign on an easel says "COME ONE, COME ALL /

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl had talent, anyone could  see that. And *she* wasn't some fly- by-nighter, she was just a good clean  kid...

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL GYMNASIUM
dialogues.text: A young man holding a saxophone is just leaving the makes stage to a smattering of applause. Birdy walks out to the baby grand that has been set out center stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If she was going to have a career  she'd need a responsible adult looking  out for her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We track up the rows of folding chairs that have been set out on the gym floor for the audience of students and par many of whom fan themselves with programs. We come to res on Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...some kind of... manager. She'd  have contracts to look at, be going  on tours, playing on the radio maybe.  I could help her sort through all of  that, without charging her an arm  and a leg, just enough to get by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy begins to play for the quietly attentive audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is among the crowd streaming from the gym into the war summer night. He looks around the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I could afford to charge less  than the usual manager, not having  to put up a big front like a lot of  these phonies. And I could be with  her, enough to keep myself feeling  OK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trace of a frown as he spots her leaning against a car, laughing, passing a cigarette back and forth with another student--a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why couldn't that work?... Why  not?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy's easy smile remains as Ed approaches, but the boy' drops; he puts on a face more suitable for meeting adults

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mr Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Birdy. I thought that was  very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, in there? I messed up a little  bit in the scherzo. I guess, if nobody  noticed, it's OK. Mr Crane, this is  Tony, a friend of mine. Tony, Mr  Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The teens wait for the adult to direct the  conversation; Ed has nothing to say. At length, he clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, congratulations. I guess  I'll be getting home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TURANDOT SUITE
dialogues.text: It is morning. We are tracking past an unmade bed toward bathroom, where we hear water running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Anyway, that's what I was thinking  about in the days leading up to the  trial. It seemed like once that was  over, I'd be ready for a new start.  Freddy Riedenschneider was very  optimistic. He was busy preparing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have rounded the open bathroom door to find Riedenschn hunched over the sink, toothbrush in hand, spitting out w He rises, looks at himself in the mirror, sprinkles some  tonic in his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And finally it came... the first  day of the trial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider runs his fingers through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What Riedenschneider called the  Big Show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He straightens his tie, gives his neck a twist.

dialogues.speaker: COURTROOM
dialogues.text: We are close on the back of Riedenschneider's gleaming ha He is sitting at the defense table. There is a murmur of a crowd that has yet to be called to order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the judge? How come there's  no judge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Frank sit next to each other in the first gallery directly behind Riedenschneider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Where's the judge, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed shrugs. Frank looks at Riedenschneider's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How come the judge doesn't come  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge comes in last. He'll come  in when Doris gets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where's Doris? I thought we started  at ten. Hey, Riedenschneider, where's  Doris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider is curt:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late? How can she be late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider doesn't answer; Frank turns to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She's in prison, Ed. None of *us*  are in prison, and yet we're not  late. We're on time, Ed. How can  Doris be late? What, they don't have  wake-up calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murmur of the crowd subsides as a door behind the jud bench opens and the judge hurriedly enters. The gallery rises but the judge quickly waves them back d and, rather than seating himself, leans forward over his  desk to give a peremptory beckoning wave to Riedenschneid and the prosecutor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counselors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider, puzzled, approaches the bench, as does h counterpart from the other table. The judge, still leanin forward, speaks to them in a low voice that is not audibl from the gallery. The crowd has started murmuring again, also in hushed ton Frank leans in toward Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on, Ed? I thought there  would be arguments. The bailiff, and  so forth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, also puzzled, is watching Riedenschneider, who sudden stiffens. As the judge continues to talk, Riedenschneider looks back over his shoulder at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ed, what is this? Is this  procedure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two lawyers nod at the judge and walk back to their  respective tables. The judge now summons a uniformed man  standing to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the judge and the bailiff confer, Riedenschneider look down at his desk and, for something to do, straightens va papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
