dialogues.text: I don't understand... We had a real  shot at it... We could have won this  thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bailiff Announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the matter of the State of  California versus Doris Crane, Case  Number 87249 assigned to this Superior  Court...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the bailiff drones, Riedenschneider shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It doesn't make any sense...

dialogues.speaker: BARBERSHOP
dialogues.text: Late afternoon sun slants in. The shop, not open for business, is very still. Ed, in hi courtroom suit, sits in one of the vinyl chairs that line the wall, hunched forward, forearms on his knees. Frank, also still in his suit, is up in one of the barber chairs, one hand cupped to his forehead, weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd hanged herself. I'd brought  her a dress to wear to court and  she'd used the belt. I didn't  understand it either. At first I  thought maybe it had something to do  with me, that she'd figured out  somehow how I fit into it and couldn't  stand it, couldn't stand knowing...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Night. Ed is in bed, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That wasn't it, I would find out  later. For now, everything just seemed  ruined...

dialogues.speaker: METROPOLE LOBBY
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider is at the cashier's desk, checking out. B him a bellman's cart is piled high with his bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Freddy Riedenschneider went back  to Sacramento still shaking his head,  saying it was the biggest  disappointment of his professional  career...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Day. Frank's kitchen. Frank sits at his kitchen table, staring, in a bathrobe t over his pyjamas, unshaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Frankie fell to pieces. I suspect  he was drinking; anyway, he stopped  coming to work...

dialogues.speaker: BARBERSHOP
dialogues.text: Ed, in his smock, works on a customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That left me to keep the place  going, or the bank would've taken  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he uses the electric clippers, a cigarette plumes betw his lips. He squints against the smoke drifting past his  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...*I* was the principal barber now.  I hired a new man for the second  chair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed's former chair is indeed being manned by a newcomer, a gangly young man who animatedly chats up his customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'd hired the guy who did the  least gabbing when he came in for an  interview. But I guess the new man  had only kept quiet because he was  nervous; once he had the job, he  talked from the minute I opened the  shop in the morning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is evening. Ed is locking the barbershop as, next to h on the sidewalk, the new man continues to chat, gesticula to illustrate his store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...until I locked up at night. For  all I know, he talked to himself on  the way home.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Ed walks along the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...When *I* walked home, it seemed  like everyone avoided looking at  me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, none of the passers-by establish eye contact; the averted eyes make the crowd a faceless throng.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...as if I'd caught some disease.  This thing with Doris, nobody wanted  to talk about it; it was like I was  a ghost walking down the street...

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: As Ed lets himself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And when I got home now, the place  felt empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on the couch and, after a beat, takes a cigarette pack from his pocket and taps out a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I sat in the house, but there was  nobody there. I was a ghost; I didn't  see anyone; no one saw me...

dialogues.speaker: BARBERSHOP
dialogues.text: Ed is in his smock again, operating the clippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I was the barber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drone of the clippers has continued over the black. A voice fades up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So two blocks later I look at the  change she gave me and, golly, I'm  two bits short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two bits short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I walk back over to Linton's,  find this gal--big argument; she  doesn't even recall the transaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No recollection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't recall the transaction, no  recollection, so I said, Look, dear...

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: We are looking at a magazine story. Its headline, over an illustration of a cresting wave, is: WAVE OF THE FUTURE. Underneath are black-and-white photographs of heavy equip and racks of clothing on motorized tracks. Subheadlines r NEXT TO GODLINESS - Dry Cleaning Sweeps The Nation - The  Thoroughly Modern Way To Clean. Ed sits in one of the vinyl chairs, staring at Life magaz The offscreen conversation drones on as the new man works a customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...go ahead, look at the menu, if  you're in before six o'clock it's  the, whatchamacallit, the--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early Bird Special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Yeah, the Early Riser...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed flips the pages of the magazine, and stops on a photog of a dark desert landscape with one bright light hovering the sky. The caption underneath: ROSWELL, NEW MEXICO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed looks up. A man in a black suit and fedora has directed the questio at the new man, who looks up from his gabbling, momentari slackjawed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Diedrickson. County medical  examiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just came for an informal chat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diedrickson looks around uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why don't I buy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed rises from his chair and, as he unbuttons his smock,  addresses the new man, who still gapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight, you OK here for a few minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whuh--uh, yeah, sure Ed, take your  time.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: It is late afternoon, dusty and empty. Ed and Diedrickson sit on adjacent stools, Diedrickson co his hat lower to its man-sitting-at-a-bar position. As the bartender approaches:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want something  stiffer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed shrugs and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. Diedrickson interlaces his fingers on the bart and stares at them. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...County M. E. does an autopsy on  anyone who dies in custody. I don't  know if you knew that. It's routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed doesn't answer. Diedrickson, after some more staring a his hands, plows on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Doesn't become a matter of public  record unless there's foul play.  However. I don't believe I'm  *prohibited* from telling you this.  I guess I'm not obliged to tell you,  either. I don't exactly know.  But  if *I* were the man, I'd want to be  told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh... thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender has set down the drinks. Diedrickson waits for him to leave. He takes a hit from h glass. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry to add to your burden,  Crane, but I'd want to know it it  was me. Your wife was pregnant. First  trimester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, there it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mutters to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hell, I hope I've done the right  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife and I had not... performed  the sex act in many years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diedrickson stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring) ...Jesus. (aloud) ...Well, that's not really my  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is hastily digging for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry. Well, there it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves a couple of bills on the bar and mumbles as he  leaves:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Good luck, Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His retreating footsteps echo down the bar.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: It is a dingy hallway lit by bare bulbs. Ed stands in the middle background, knocking on a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris and I had never really talked  much. I don't think that's a bad  thing, necessarily. But it was funny:  now I wanted to talk--now, with  everyone gone. I was alone, with  secrets I didn't want and no one to  tell them to anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Ed is admitted by the unseen tenant.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT
dialogues.text: We hear a low murmuring as we slowly pan the apartment. I is overfurnished with heavy, ornate chairs, sideboards, c too big for the space and all going too seed. Surface are are covered with yellowing lacework or exotic brocades; t one lamp has a veil thrown over it to further scrim down feeble light. Our pan brings us onto Ed seated at a small card table ac from a small elderly woman in a shawl who is the source o the murmuring. Her eyes are squeezed shut in concentratio as she mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I visited a woman who was supposed  to have powers in communicating with  those who had passed across, as she  called it. She said that people who  passed across were picky about who  they'd communicate with, not like  most people you run into on this  side...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman opens her eyes and looks at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giff me your hant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed places his hand in the center of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so you needed a guide who they  didn't mind talking to, someone with  a gift for talking to souls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed looks at the woman's spotted and vein-lined hand as it rests upon his. Her mumbling resumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, first she told me that my  wife was in a peaceful place, that  our souls were still connected by  some spiritual bond, that she had  never stopped loving me even though  she'd done some things she wasn't  proud of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed looks up at the old woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...She was reading me like a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is stealing a glance at Ed to check his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And then she started talking about  'Dolores' this and 'Dolores' that  and was there anything I wanted to  tell 'Dolores,' and I knew I'd just  be telling it to the old bat. And  even if somehow Doris could hear, it  wouldn't be on account of this so- called medium.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ed is leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a phony. Just another gabber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed emerges from the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was turning into Ann Nirdlinger,  Big Dave's wife. I had to turn my  back on the old lady, on the veils,  on the ghosts, on the dead, before  they all sucked me in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed disappears into the night.

dialogues.speaker: ABUNDAS HOUSE
dialogues.text: It is night. We are looking through the screen door. Walt Abundas sits in yellow lamplight by a small table on the  side of the staircase, over which papers are strewn. He i murmuring into the telephone as he examines the papers,  glasses halfway down his nose, a drink in one hand. Ed's hand enters to rap on the door. Walter looks up, set the phone down and comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, how're you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm OK, Walter, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter opens the door to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so damn sorry about your loss.  Terrible thing. Just damn terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy's in the parlor--I'm on long  distance here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Walter. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: PARLOR
dialogues.text: Birdy also has papers spread across a table in front of h homework. She looks up at Ed's entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Birdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't seen you since... I'm  terribly sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed sits across from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've certainly missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy, I've been doing a lot of  thinking. There are a lot of things  that haven't worked out for me. Life  has dealt me some bum cards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is loading a cigarette into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...or maybe I just haven't played  'em right, I don't know. But you're--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop doesn't like people smoking in  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed stares. This takes a moment to register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy lowers her voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I have a cigarette in here  when he's away. Never when he's in  the house. He can smell it a mile  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is pocketing the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure... Sure, it's his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he keeps telling me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed smiles thinly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, uh... my point is you're  young. A kid really, your whole life  ahead of you. But it's not too soon  to start thinking... to start making  opportunities for yourself. Before  it all washes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure, I guess. Pop says so  too. I work pretty hard at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's swell. However, the music, if  you want to pursue it, well, the  lessons from Mrs Swan, they'll only  take you so far. There's this guy in  San Francisco, I've made inquiries,  everybody says he's the best. Trained  lots of people who've gone on to  have big concert careers, symphony  orchestras, the works. His name is  Jacques Carcanogues. I'm not sure  I'm pronouncing it right. Anyway,  he's a Frenchman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got talent, anyone could see  that. And he's the best. If he thinks  a student has talent, he'll take 'em  on for next to nothing. You're a  cinch to be accepted, I could cover  the cost of the lessons, like I said,  it's pretty modest--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr Crane--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to do it. I can't stand by  and watch more things go down the  drain. You're young, you don't  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez, Mr Crane, I don't know. I hadn't  really thought about a career or  stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you haven't. Look, just go  meet him as a favor to me. I talked  to this guy. Hope I pronounced his  name right. He sounded very busy,  but he's not a bad egg; he loosened  up a little when I told him how  talented you are. He agreed to see  you this Saturday. He said maybe you  were a diamond in the rough. His  words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geez, Mr Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just see him, as a favor to me.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO WAITING ROOM
dialogues.text: It is a small square room with straightbacked chairs set  against the walls. At the far end of the room a door lead to a studio from which piano music dully emanates; it is fast and difficult piece of music. Ed sits waiting. He is the only adult; two or three young of different ages sit apparently waiting for their lesson Ed looks at one of the waiting boys in a white shirt and tie. He is perhaps eleven. His hair is greased back in a  Junior Contour. Another boy, in a cardigan sweater, sports a Butch. The piano piece is ending. There is the murmur of voices. Dull footsteps. The studio door swings open. A small man in a rumpled black suit smudged with cigarett ash is bowing Birdy out the door. He has a goatee and a  knotted foulard. His eyes flit over the waiting room and  settle on Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You are ze fahzer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Uh... family friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Carcanogues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at Birdy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You wait, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mr K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jerk of Carcanogues' head bids Ed rise.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO
dialogues.text: Ed enters, uncomfortable. He looks around, taking in the  high-ceilinged space, which is dominated by a grand piano Carcanogues has followed him and now runs water from a ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak to you on ze phone, non? You  have a special interest in music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah yes, a music lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't pretend to be an expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He uncaps a small bottle of pills, shakes two into his pa tosses them back and washes them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Ah-hah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He twists a cigarette into a long holder, sticks it in hi mouth and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? How'd she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This elicits a Gallic frown of consideration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ze girl?... She seems like a very  nice girl. She *plays*, monsieur,  like a very nice girl. Ztinks. Very  nice girl. However, ztinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is not so hard to understand. Her  playing, very polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she make mistakes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another gallic moue:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mistake, no, it says E-flat, she  plays E-flat. Ping-ping. Hit the  right note, always. Very proper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, no mistakes,  she's just a kid--I thought you taught  the, uh, the--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but that is just what I cannot  teach. I cannot teach her to have a  soul. Look, monsieur, play the piano,  is not about the fingers. *Done*  with the fingers, yes. But the music,  she is inside. Inside, monsieur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A two-handed gesture, indicating his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The music start here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waggles his fingers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...come out through here; then,  maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wave takes in the heavens:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...she can go up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look, I don't claim to be an  expert--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you listen to me, for I am  expert. That girl, she give me a  headache. She cannot play. Nice girl.  Very clever hands. Nice girl. Someday,  I think, maybe, she make a very good  typist.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVING
dialogues.text: We are driving through the rural countryside of northern  California. It is a two-lane road with little traffic. Su strobes the car through the passing trees. Ed drives, glaring. Birdy, next to him, seems unperturbed ever cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I stank, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But more or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm no expert, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter, Mr Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure there's a dozen teachers  better than this clown. More  qualified. Goddamn phony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it doesn't matter. Really, I'm  not interested in playing music  professionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm not certain I'll have a career  at all, and if I do, I'll probably  be a veterinarian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do appreciate the interest you've  taken, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah... it's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only sorry that I didn't play  better for you. I know it would've  made you happy. You know what you  are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an enthusiast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Yeah. Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loads a cigarette into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I guess I've been all wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I do appreciate it, Mr Crane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches over to touch his thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I wanted to make you happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is leaning over his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I want to do it, Mr Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is shocked:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches awkwardly, wanting to push her away but not wa to be violent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mr Crane, it's OK, please--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blare of an oncoming horn. Ed looks up, one hand struggling with Birdy, the other on the wheel. The oncoming car. Ed swerves, tires screech into a skid, Birdy screams. CRASH: the car hits a roadside tree. BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time slows down right before an  accident, and I had time to think  about things. I thought about what  an undertaker had told me once--that  your hair keeps growing, for a while  anyway, after you die...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hubcap is skipping in slow motion along the road and th off the road, down an embankment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and then it stops. I thought,  what keeps it growing? Is it like a  plant in soil? What goes out of the  soil? The soul? And when does the  hair realize that it's gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are high, looking down at Ed, who is motionless, head  resting on the steering wheel of the stopped car. We boom down toward his, slowly rotating as we move in. As we mov we lose focus; Ed becomes more and more blurry. The blurry shape is now slowly spinning away from us, a b revolving disc spinning up into the darkness until it  disappears, leaving only black.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Ed sits on the front porch of his bungalow, smoking a  cigarette in the late afternoon light. A dog barks next door; a distant screen door slams; child are playing somewhere up the street. Ed looks down at his watch. It is 5:30. Something attracts his attention: at the foot of his driv stands a man in a cream-colored suit and hat. He is a sma figure, perfectly still, staring at the gravel driveway. After a beat he lifts up a small clipboard, squints at th house, and jots something down. He finishes writing, screws the lid back onto his pen, an is sticking it into a breast pocket when he realizes he i being watched. His manner instantly warms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man starts up the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I notice you still have peastone in  your driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course, you don't have to  rejuvenate that once every couple of  years, don't you, when the peastone  thins out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Where does it go, huh? Like the  odd sock. But you *know* where it  goes--you probably pick pieces of it  off your lawn all the time, churn it  up with your lawn mower, sweep it  off the walk here--pain in the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed shrugs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't bother me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, have you ever considered tar  Macadam? People think it's just for  public works and commercial purposes,  roads, parking lots, so forth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls into the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but we have the technology now to  bring it to the homeowner, the  individual consumer, at a very  reasonable price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris emerges from the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mind if I show you the  specifications?--Evening, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris gives him a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're *you* selling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man gives a practiced laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ma'am, I was just telling your  husband here about tar Macadam, for  your home driveway here--these are  the specs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris takes the brochure he has pulled from a small case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's the modern way to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris tears the brochure in half and hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man gazes at her. His smile fades fast and he and Dor stare at each other, two hard cases. He turns stiffly and stalks off. Once his gaze has broken, Doris turns as well. She stalks the stairs to the porch and bangs through the screen fron door of the house, letting it slam behind her. Quiet, early evening. Ed sits, smoking. At length he rises and goes in to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dim, no lights on yet. We hear banging and clomping from the kitchen. Doris emerges with a clinking sound, chasing ice cubes ar a drink with a swizzle stick. Her face is still hard-set. With a groan of its old upholstery springs she sits onto couch. Ed sits as well. He draws on his cigarette, drags an asht closer on the coffee table. She sips. He puffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Doris--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, don't say anything. I'm alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sit. The light is failing. The clink of ice cubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the black we hear machine noise of indistinct origin. the noise becomes more defined we also hear shouting, fai distant:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you there? Are you awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blurry white disc is fading up. As it focuses it resolv into the reflector worn by a white-robed doctor, leaning close. He leans away, murmuring:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming around. Can you talk,  sir? These men have to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is lying in a hospital bed. His face is bandaged and o side is grotesquely swollen. The machine noise is life  support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sir? Are you awake? He's awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two police officers, Persky and Krebs, lean in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you awake?... Is he awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crane? We have to tell you, as soon  as you're conscious--is he conscious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... you're under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as the doctor lets us, we  gotta move you. Does he understand  that? We're supposed to tell him.  Are you conscious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll go to the prison hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under arrest for murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed's speech is thickened by injuries and anesthesia:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy... I didn't mean to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birdy. The girl. No, the girl's OK.  Broken clavicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's the collarbone, Crane.  Broken. She's OK though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he understands? He's under arrest  for murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say? Does he understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said OK. Is that what he said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Krebs raises his voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're under arrest for the murder  of Creighton Tolliver! Do you  understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voices are fading away:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Does he understand?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light glimmers in water. We are drifting down, down, down We bring in languidly waving arms--the arms of a child, w to keep himself submerged. It is a ten-year-old boy stari wide-eyed, at something in front of him. Bubbles  intermittently stream from his open mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pansy. A kid diving at a waterhole  outside of town had found his car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reverse shows the car, also submerged, with Creighton Tolliver inside, also wide-eyed, his hairpiece attached a only one corner, the rest of it waving free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They'd winched it out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are tracking laterally across a line of faces: seated  men. The men rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and found he'd been beaten, just  like Big Dave said--beaten to death...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We arc around a judge entering the chamber through the sm door behind his raised bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Inside the briefcase were the  partnership papers I'd signed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge seats himself and we resume out lateral track o the jury, now reseating itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...showing that I'd given him ten  grand. For the district attorney...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In response to a prompt from the judge the district attor rises to read the charge. His voice plays distantly, mute the words not discernible under the continuing voice-over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that made it fall into place: I'd  gotten Doris to steal the money, the  pansy had gotten wise somehow, and  I'd had to kill him to cover my  tracks. I was in a spot. I called in  Freddy Riedenschneider...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider rises into frame at the defense table. As listens to the charge:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and signed the house over to him.  He said he didn't ordinarily work  that cheap, but he figured he owed  me something since the last one hadn't  played out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drone of the D.A. has ended and Riedenschneider's ech voice drops into the hole:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not guilty, your honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to tell him the whole story,  but Riedenschneider stopped me. He  said the story made his head hurt,  and anyway he didn't see any way of  using it without putting me on the  hot seat for the murder of Big Dave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider claps Ed reassuringly on the shoulder as sits next to him. Ed still wears a cast on one arm and on leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He told me not to worry, though,  said he'd think of something, Freddy  Riedenschneider wouldn't let me down.

dialogues.speaker: JAIL
dialogues.text: We are tracking in on Ed, lying on the bunk in his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...They put me on twenty-four-hour  deathwatch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reverse track shows a guard on a tilted-back straightba chair, outside the cell door, staring at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so that I couldn't Cheat Justice  like they said my wife had done...

dialogues.speaker: COURTROOM
dialogues.text: The district attorney is rising again, this time to addre the jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But in front of the jury they had  it that Doris was a saint; the whole  plan had been mine, I was a Svengali  who'd forced Doris to join my criminal  enterprise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The district attorney is pointing at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...cynically used his own wife as a  cat's paw in a scheme of diabolical  cunning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On and on it went, how I'd used Doris  and then let her take the fall. That  stuff smarted because some of it was  close to being true...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The district attorney seats himself. The jury's eyes turn Freddy Riedenschneider, who studies the tabletop in front him, either digesting the D.A.'s opening statement, or se inspiration for his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And then it was Freddy  Riedenschneider's turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider rises, paces, begins to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I gotta hand it to him, he tossed  a lot of sand in their eyes. He talked  about how I'd lost my place in the  universe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a puny player on the great world's  stage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...how I was too ordinary to be the  criminal mastermind the D.A. made me  out to be, how there was some greater  scheme at work that the state had  yet to unravel, and he threw in some  of the old truth stuff he hadn't had  a chance to trot out for Doris...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who among us is in a position to  say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He told them to look at me--look  at me close. That the closer they  looked the less sense it would all  make, that I wasn't the kind of guy  to kill a guy, that I was the barber,  for Christ's sake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan the jury, solemnly listening to Riedenschneider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I was just like them, an ordinary  man, guilty of living in a world  that had no place for me, guilty of  wanting to be a dry cleaner, sure,  but not of murder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider is striding energetically into the foregr to point a finger directly at Ed's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He said I *was* Modern Man, and  if they voted to convict me, well,  they'd be practically cinching the  noose around their own necks. He  told them to look not at the facts  but at the meaning of the facts, and  then he said the facts *had* no  meaning. It was a pretty good speech,  and even had me going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tap on the shoulder turns Ed around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...until Frankie interrupted it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank socks Ed, sending him clattering to the floor. A bailiff immediately restrains him, but Frank looms over Ed, bellowing through tears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of man *are* you? What  kind of man *are* you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riedenschneider interposes his body between Frank's and E loudly protesting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move for a mistrial, your honor!  Move for a mistrial! This outrageous  display cannot help but prejudice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed moves to get up, but Riedenschneider, with a sidelong  glance and furtive gesture, motions for him to stay on th floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and inflame the passions of these  twelve fine men and women...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, he got his mistrial, but  the well had run dry. There was  nothing left to mortgage;  Riedenschneider went home and the  court appointed Lloyd Garroway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is now standing next to a distinguished older gentlema who enters the plea in the new trial:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, we plead guilty, with  extenuating circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who threw me on the mercy of the  court. It was my only chance, he  said. I guess that meant I never had  a chance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge starts droning the sentence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a menace to society... a predator  on his own wife, his business  associates, on an innocent young  girl... social contract... line  crossed... the offender forfeits the  right to his own life... I hereby  order that you be taken to a place  of confinement...

dialogues.speaker: PRISON HALLWAY
dialogues.text: We are tracking down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't buying any of that Modern  Man stuff, or the uncertainty stuff,  or any of the mercy stuff either.  No, he was going by the book, and  the book said I got the chair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is in the cell at the end of the hall, lying on his bu hands clasped behind his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so here I am. At first I didn't  know how I got here. I knew step by  step of course, which is what I've  told you, step by step; but I couldn't  see any pattern...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Ed sits at the little table next to his bunk, writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Now that I'm near the end, I'm  glad that this men's magazine paid  me to tell my story. Writing it has  helped me sort it all out. They're  paying five cents a word, so you'll  pardon me if sometimes I've told you  more than you wanted to know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recent issues of the magazine, Gent, and its sister  publication Nugget lie on the little desk. Their lurid co depict feature stories like I WAS ABDUCTED BY ALIENS and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But now, all the disconnected  things seems to hook up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed sets aside the pen, lies down on his bunk, and closes eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's the funny thing about going  away, knowing the date you're gonna  die--and the men's magazine wanted  me to tell how that felt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a pulsing treble hum. Ed opens his eyes. The door to his cell is open. He rises and goes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ed, alone, walks down the hallway. The pulsing treble hum louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, it's like pulling away from  the maze. While you're in the maze  you go through willy-nilly, turning  where you think you have to turn,  banging into dead ends, one thing  after another...

dialogues.speaker: PRISON YARD
dialogues.text: Ed emerges into the empty prison yard ringed by high ston walls. A hard spotlight shines down from above. Ed squint into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But get some distance on it, and  all those twists and turns, why,  they're the shape of your life. It's  hard to explain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spotlight is from a hovering flying saucer. We see it revolving underside and, as it irregularly cants, a bit o its top bubble. After spinning briefly, it tips and flies away, carrying tremolo hum with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But seeing it whole gives you  some peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed turns and re-enters the prison.

dialogues.speaker: ED'S CELL
dialogues.text: Ed is lying on his bunk, eyes closed, hands clasped behin his head. A hand enters to shake him awake. Three men loom over him: two guards and another man weari a surplice and holding a bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The men's magazine also asked  about remorse. Yeah, I guess I'm  sorry about the pain I caused other  people...

dialogues.speaker: PRISON HALLWAY
dialogues.text: He is walking the last mile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but I don't regret anything. Not  a thing. I used to. I used to regret  being the barber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door at the end opens: An electric chair. Straps open, and waiting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I dont know where I'm being taken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is placed in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't know what waits for me,  beyond the earth and sky. But I'm  not afraid to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man stoops at his feet. He has a bucket of water and a  straight razor. He waggles the razor in the water and starts shaving a pa of Ed's calf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Maybe the things I don't understand  will be clearer there, like when a  fog blows away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed watches as the razor makes the trip from his leg to th bucket of water, which begins to spot with small floating hairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Maybe Doris will be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are strapping him in, connecting the electrodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And maybe there I can tell her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...all those things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thin man in a dark suit and fedora stands by the switch As he reaches for the switch, Ed looks up into the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...they don't have words for here.
